translated: Abhidharma Collection of Categories Treatise, Scroll 18
Composed by Venerable Vasumitra
Translated by Tripiá¹­aka Master Xuanzang on Imperial Order

The chapter on discerning and determining, the eighth chapter. Form dharmas are included in eleven realms, eleven bases, and one aggregate, are known by eight knowledges excluding knowledge of others' minds and the knowledge of cessation, are cognized by six consciousnesses, and are increased by the universal and cultivated contaminants of the desire and form realms.
Only form dharmas are included in ten realms, ten bases, and one aggregate, are not known by any knowledge, are cognized by five consciousnesses, and are not increased by any contaminants.
Formless dharmas are included in eight realms, two bases, and four aggregates, are known by ten knowledges, are cognized by one consciousness, and are increased by all contaminants.

Only formless dharmas are included in seven realms, one base, and four aggregates, are known by two knowledges, namely knowledge of others' minds and the knowledge of cessation, are not cognized by any consciousness, are increased by all contaminants of the formless realm, by the two categories of contaminants of the desire and form realms, and by the universal contaminants eliminated by the paths of seeing suffering and its cause.

The dharmas that are seen are included in one realm, one sense base, and one aggregate. They are known by seven knowledges, excluding the knowledge of the cessation of suffering and the knowledge of the path. They are cognized by two consciousnesses. The latent tendencies of the entire desire realm and form realm, and those to be eliminated by cultivation increase in them.

The dharmas that are only seen are included in one realm and one sense base, but are not included in an aggregate. They are not known by any knowledges. They are cognized by one consciousness. The latent tendencies do not increase in them.

The dharmas that are not seen are included in seventeen realms, eleven sense bases, and five aggregates. They are known by ten knowledges. They are cognized by five consciousnesses. All the latent tendencies increase in them.

The dharmas that are only not seen are included in seventeen realms, eleven sense bases, and four aggregates. They are known by three knowledges: the knowledge of the cessation of suffering, the knowledge of the path, and the knowledge of others' minds. They are cognized by four consciousnesses. The entire formless realm, the two parts of the desire realm, and the non-pervasive latent tendencies eliminated by the paths of seeing suffering and seeing its cause increase in them.

The dharmas that are resistant are included in ten realms, ten sense bases, and one aggregate. They are known by seven knowledges, excluding the knowledge of the cessation of suffering and the knowledge of the path. They are cognized by six consciousnesses. The pervasive [latent tendencies] of the desire realm and form realm, and those eliminated by cultivation increase in them.

Only the unobstructed-indeterminate are included in ten elements, ten sense bases, and are not included in the aggregates. They are not known by any cognition, are cognized by five consciousnesses, and are not increased by any latent afflictions.

The obstructed-indeterminate are included in eight elements, two sense bases, and five aggregates. They are known by ten cognitions, cognized by one consciousness, and are increased by all latent afflictions.

Only the unobstructed-indeterminate are included in eight elements, two sense bases, and four aggregates. They are known by three cognitions: cognition of others' minds, cognition of cessation, and cognition of the path. They are not cognized by any consciousness, and are increased by all latent afflictions of the formless realm, the desire realm, the two parts of the form realm, and the universal and specific afflictions abandoned by the paths of seeing and cultivation of the truths of suffering and origination.

The contaminated are included in eighteen elements, twelve sense bases, and five aggregates. They are known by eight cognitions excluding cognition of cessation and cognition of the path. They are cognized by six consciousnesses, and are increased by all latent afflictions.

Only the contaminated are included in fifteen elements, ten sense bases, and are not included in the aggregates. They are known by two cognitions: cognition of suffering and cognition of origination. They are cognized by five consciousnesses, and are increased by all latent afflictions.

As for the uncontaminated dharmas, they are categorized as three realms, two sense bases, and five aggregates. They are known by eight knowledges excluding the knowledges of suffering and of origination. They are cognized by one consciousness, and they are neither associated with nor increase the proclivities.

As for the dharmas that are only uncontaminated, they are not categorized as realms, sense bases, or aggregates. They are known by two knowledges, i.e., the knowledge of cessation and the knowledge of the path. They are not cognized by any consciousness, and they are neither associated with nor increase the proclivities.

As for conditioned dharmas, they are categorized as the eighteen elements, twelve sense bases, and five aggregates. They are known by nine knowledges excluding the knowledge of cessation. They are cognized by six consciousnesses, and they are associated with and increase all the proclivities.

As for the dharmas that are only conditioned, they are categorized as seventeen elements, eleven sense bases, and five aggregates. They are known by four knowledges, i.e., the knowledge of the mind of another, the knowledge of suffering, the knowledge of the cause, and the knowledge of the path. They are cognized by five consciousnesses, and they are associated with and increase all the proclivities.ğŸ”½As for unconditioned dharmas, they are categorized as one element and one sense base, but not as aggregates. They are known by six knowledges, excluding the knowledge of the mind of another, the knowledge of suffering, the knowledge of the cause, and the knowledge of the path. They are cognized by one consciousness, and they are neither associated with nor increase the proclivities.

As for the dharmas that are only unconditioned, they are not categorized as realms, sense bases, or aggregates. They are known by one knowledge, i.e., the knowledge of cessation. They are not cognized by any consciousness, and they are neither associated with nor increase the proclivities.

dharmas with conflict and without conflict, worldly and transcendent dharmas, dharmas included in the realms and not included in the realms, dharmas with relishing and without relishing, dharmas based on indulgence and based on renunciation, dharmas that accord with the fetters and that do not accord with the fetters, dharmas that accord with grasping and that do not accord with grasping, dharmas that accord with the bonds and that do not accord with the bonds, should be understood in the same way as contaminated and uncontaminated dharmas.

Indeterminate dharmas are categorized as ten elements, four spheres, and five aggregates. They are known by ten knowledges and cognized by three consciousnesses. All of the desire realm, the pervasive contaminants of the form and formless realms, and the contaminants to be eliminated by cultivation increase in them.

Indeterminate dharmas alone are not categorized as elements, spheres, or aggregates. They are known by two knowledges, namely, the knowledge of cessation and the knowledge of the path. They are not cognized by any consciousness. The two classes of contaminants of the desire realm and those eliminated by the path of insight into the truths of accumulation increase in them.

Indeterminate dharmas are categorized as the eighteen sense spheres, twelve sense fields, and five aggregates. They are known by eight knowledges excluding the knowledge of cessation and the knowledge of the path. They are discerned by six consciousnesses. All of the propensities of the form and formless realms and the two parts and the propensities eliminated by insight into the truth of accumulation of the desire realm increase in them.

Only indeterminate dharmas are not categorized as sense spheres, sense fields, or aggregates. They are not known by any knowledges. They are discerned by three consciousnesses. The two parts of the form and formless realms and the propensities eliminated by insight into the truths of cessation and path of the desire realm increase in them.

Obscured dharmas are categorized as ten sense spheres, four sense fields, and five aggregates. They are known by eight knowledges excluding the knowledge of cessation and the knowledge of the path. They are discerned by three consciousnesses. All propensities increase in them.

Only obscured dharmas are not categorized as sense spheres, sense fields, or aggregates. They are not known by any knowledges. They are not discerned by any consciousnesses. The two parts of the three realms and the propensities eliminated by insight into the truths of cessation and path of the desire realm increase in them.

As for the undefiled dharmas, they are categorized as the eighteen realms, twelve sense fields, and five aggregates. They are known by the ten knowledges and cognized by the six consciousnesses. The entanglements of the three realms that are universally accessible and those that are eliminated by cultivation increase in accordance with them.

As for the undefiled dharmas alone, they are not categorized as the eight realms, eight sense fields, or aggregates. They are known by two knowledges, i.e., the knowledge of cessation and the knowledge of the path. They are cognized by three consciousnesses and do not increase in accordance with the entanglements.

As for the dharmas that should be cultivated, they are categorized as ten realms, four sense fields, and five aggregates. They are known by nine knowledges excluding the knowledge of cessation. They are cognized by three consciousnesses and the entanglements of the three realms that are universally accessible and those eliminated by cultivation increase in accordance with them.

As for the dharmas that should be cultivated alone, they are not categorized as realms, sense fields, or aggregates. They are known by one knowledge, i.e., the knowledge of the path. They are not cognized by any consciousness and do not increase in accordance with the entanglements.

As for the dharmas that should not be cultivated, they are categorized as the eighteen realms, twelve sense fields, and five aggregates. They are known by nine knowledges excluding the knowledge of the path. They are cognized by six consciousnesses and all the entanglements increase in accordance with them.

The dharmas that should not be cultivated are not categorized as aggregates, are included in eight sense spheres and eight sense fields, are known by one kind of knowledge, i.e., knowledge of cessation, are perceived by three kinds of consciousness, and increase with the three realmsâ€™ two kinds of passions and with the passions that are eliminated during the path of cultivation, as well as with the passions that are eliminated by the path of insight into the truths of suffering and its cause.

The defiled dharmas are categorized as ten sense bases and four sense fields and five aggregates, are known by eight kinds of knowledge excluding knowledge of cessation and the path, are perceived by three kinds of consciousness, and increase with all the propensities.

The dharmas that are exclusively defiled are not categorized as sense bases, sense fields, or aggregates, are not known by any of the knowledges, are not perceived by any of the consciousnesses, and increase with the passions of the three realms that are eliminated by the paths of insight and cultivation, as well as with the passions that are not eliminated by the paths of insight and cultivation.

The undefiled dharmas are categorized as the eighteen sense elements, twelve sense bases, and five aggregates, are known by ten kinds of knowledge, are perceived by six consciousnesses, and increase with the universal and particular passions of the three realms that are eliminated by the path of cultivation.

The dharmas that are exclusively undefiled are not categorized as aggregates, are included in eight sense bases and eight sense fields, are known by two kinds of knowledge, i.e., knowledge of cessation and the path, are perceived by three kinds of consciousness, and do not increase with any of the propensities.
The same is true of the dharmas that are sinful and not sinful.

The dharmas with retribution are categorized as ten elements, four sense spheres, and five aggregates. They are known by eight knowledges excluding the knowledge of cessation and the knowledge of the path. They are discerned by three consciousnesses. All of the passions of the realm of desire, and the passions that are universal in the realms of form and of non-form, and those that are to be eliminated by cultivation increase in them.

The dharmas that are only retribution are not categorized as elements, sense bases, or aggregates. They are not known by any knowledges. They are not discerned by any consciousnesses. The two parts eliminated by the path of insight in the realm of desire and those eliminated by the knowledge of the truth of suffering increase in them.

The dharmas without retribution are categorized as eighteen elements, twelve sense bases, and five aggregates. They are known by ten knowledges. They are discerned by six consciousnesses. All of those in the realms of form and of non-form, the two parts in the realm of desire, and the passions eliminated by the knowledge of the truth of suffering increase in them.

The dharmas that are only without retribution are categorized as eight elements and eight sense bases, but not as aggregates. They are known by two knowledges, the knowledge of cessation and the knowledge of the path. They are discerned by three consciousnesses. The two parts in the realms of form and of non-form, and those eliminated by the knowledge of the truths of suffering and of the cause of suffering increase in them.

The seen phenomena are included in two realms, two bases, and two aggregates. They are known by nine knowledges excluding the knowledge of cessation. They are cognized by one consciousness. The contaminants of the two realms that are with attachment and the pure universal contaminants associated with views increase in them.

The phenomena that are only seen are not included in any realms, bases, or aggregates. They are not known by any knowledges. They are not cognized by any consciousnesses. No contaminants increase in them.

The phenomena that are not seen are included in seventeen realms, eleven bases, and five aggregates. They are known by ten knowledges. They are cognized by six consciousnesses. All contaminants increase in them.

The phenomena that are only not seen are included in sixteen realms, ten bases, and three aggregates. They are known by one knowledge, namely the knowledge of cessation. They are cognized by five consciousnesses, excluding the pure universal contaminants associated with views and the contaminants that are with attachment to the object of the knowledge of cessation. The remaining pure universal contaminants increase in them.

The internal phenomena are included in twelve realms, six bases, and two aggregates. They are known by nine knowledges excluding the knowledge of cessation. They are cognized by one consciousness. All contaminants increase in them.

Only internal phenomena are included in twelve sense bases, six sense bases, and one aggregate. They are not known by any cognition, are not cognized by any consciousness, and are not associated with any latent tendencies.
External phenomena are included in six sense bases, six sense bases, and four aggregates. They are known by ten cognitions, cognized by six consciousnesses, and associated with all latent tendencies.

Only external phenomena are included in six sense bases, six sense bases, and three aggregates. They are known by one cognition, namely the cognition of cessation, cognized by five consciousnesses, and are not associated with any latent tendencies.

Phenomena that are appropriated are included in nine sense bases, nine sense bases, and one aggregate. They are known by seven cognitions, excluding cognition of others' minds, cognition of cessation, and cognition of the path. They are cognized by five consciousnesses, and associated with the universal and cultivated afflictions of the desire and form realms.

Only phenomena that are appropriated are not included in any sense bases, not included in any sense bases, and not included in any aggregates. They are not known by any cognition, are not cognized by any consciousness, and are not associated with any latent tendencies.

Non-appropriated phenomena are included in eighteen sense bases, twelve sense bases, and five aggregates. They are known by ten cognitions, cognized by six consciousnesses, and associated with all latent tendencies.

The dharmas that are not grasped are categorized as nine elements, three sense bases, and four aggregates. Three knowledges know them, i.e., knowledge of othersâ€™ minds, knowledge of elimination, and knowledge of the path. They are discerned by one consciousness, i.e., the mental consciousness. All of the form- less realm, the two parts of the desire realm and the form realm, and the passions eliminated by the paths of insight into the truths of suffering and the origination of suffering increase them.

Mental factors are categorized as seven elements, one sense base, and one aggregate. Nine knowledges know them, excluding the knowledge of cessation. They are discerned by one consciousness, i.e., the mental consciousness. All passions increase them.

Only mental factors are categorized as seven elements, one sense base, and one aggregate. The knowledges that know them are not included in the knowledges. The consciousness that discerns them is not included in the consciousnesses. The passions that increase them are not included in the passions.
Dharmas that are not mind are categorized as eleven elements, eleven sense bases, and four aggregates. Ten knowledges know them. They are discerned by six consciousnesses. All passions increase them.

Only dharmas that are not mind are categorized as eleven elements, eleven sense bases, and four aggregates. The knowledge that knows them is not included in the knowledges. The consciousness that discerns them is not included in the consciousnesses. The passions that increase them are not included in the passions.

Dharmas that are objects of cognition are subsumed under eight sense bases, two sense fields, and four aggregates. They are known by nine knowledges except for the knowledge of cessation. They are cognized by one consciousness, and all proclivities increase them.

Dharmas that are only objects of cognition are subsumed under seven sense bases, one sense field, and three aggregates. They are known by one knowledge, namely the knowledge of the mind of another. They are not cognized by any consciousness. Proclivities of the three realms that have pure objects increase them.

Dharmas that are not objects of cognition are subsumed under eleven sense bases, eleven sense fields, and two aggregates. They are known by nine knowledges except for the knowledge of the mind of another. They are cognized by six consciousnesses. Proclivities of the three realms that have contaminated objects increase them.

Dharmas that are only not objects of cognition are subsumed under ten sense bases, ten sense fields, and one aggregate. They are known by one knowledge, namely the knowledge of cessation. They are cognized by five consciousnesses. Proclivities do not increase them.

Mental factors are subsumed under one sense base, one sense field, and three aggregates. They are known by nine knowledges except for the knowledge of cessation. They are cognized by one consciousness. All proclivities increase them.

Mental factors that are only mental factors are not subsumed under any sense bases or sense fields. They are subsumed under two aggregates. They are not known by any knowledge. They are not cognized by any consciousness. Proclivities do not increase them.

The dharmas that are not mental factors are categorized as the eighteen sense fields, the twelve sense bases, and the three aggregates. They are known by the ten knowledges and cognized by the six consciousnesses. All of the proclivities increase them.

Only the dharmas that are not mental factors are categorized as the seventeen sense fields, the eleven sense bases, and the two aggregates. They are known by one knowledge, i.e., the knowledge of cessation, and cognized by the five consciousnesses. The proclivities do not increase them.

Karmic dharmas are categorized as the three realms, the three sense bases, and the two aggregates. They are known by nine knowledges excluding the knowledge of cessation, and are cognized by the three consciousnesses. All of the proclivities increase them.

Only karmic dharmas are not categorized as sense bases or aggregates. They are not known by any of the knowledges, are not cognized by any of the consciousnesses, and are not increased by any of the proclivities.

Dharmas that are not karmic are categorized as the eighteen sense fields, the twelve sense bases, and the five aggregates. They are known by the ten knowledges and cognized by the six consciousnesses. All of the proclivities increase them.

Only dharmas that are not karmic are categorized as the fifteen sense fields, the nine sense bases, and the three aggregates. They are known by one knowledge, i.e., the knowledge of cessation, and are cognized by the three consciousnesses. The proclivities do not increase them.

The wholesome factors are categorized as ten elements, four sense spheres, and five aggregates. They are known by ten forms of knowledge. They are discerned by three forms of consciousness. The universal and particular fluxes of the three realms that are to be eliminated by cultivation increase in them.

The only wholesome factors are not categorized as elements, sense spheres, or aggregates. They are known by two forms of knowledge, i.e., the knowledge of cessation and the knowledge of the path. They are not discerned by any form of consciousness. The fluxes do not increase in them.

The unwholesome factors are categorized as ten elements, four sense spheres, and five aggregates. They are known by seven forms of knowledge, excluding the knowledge of the class, cessation, and the path. They are discerned by three forms of consciousness. All the fluxes of the realm of desire increase in them.

The only unwholesome factors are not categorized as elements, sense spheres, or aggregates. They are not known by any form of knowledge. They are not discerned by any form of consciousness. The two parts of the fluxes of the realm of desire and the universal fluxes that are eliminated by the path of insight into the truths of the origin and the path increase in them.

The indeterminate factors are categorized as eighteen elements, twelve sense spheres, and five aggregates. They are known by eight forms of knowledge, excluding the knowledge of cessation and the knowledge of the path. They are discerned by six forms of consciousness. All those of the realms of form and of non-form, the two parts of the fluxes of the realm of desire, and the universal fluxes that are eliminated by the path of insight into the truths of the origin and the path increase in them.

Only neutral dharmas are not included in the aggregates, eight elements, and eight sense bases. They are not known by any of the knowledges, are cognized by three consciousnesses, and are increased by the two parts and by the views of suffering and origin in the form and formless realms and by the non-pervasive propensities.

Dharmas that are to be eliminated by the path of insight are included in the three realms, two sense bases, and four aggregates. They are known by eight knowledges excluding the knowledge of cessation and the knowledge of the path. They are cognized by one consciousness. All the propensities that are to be eliminated by the path of insight increase them.

Only dharmas that are to be eliminated by the path of insight are not included in the realms, sense bases, or aggregates. They are not known by any of the knowledges. They are not cognized by any of the consciousnesses. They are increased by the two parts and by the views of suffering and origin in the three realms and by the non-pervasive propensities.

Dharmas that are to be eliminated by the path of cultivation are included in the eighteen elements, twelve sense bases, and five aggregates. They are known by eight knowledges excluding the knowledge of cessation and the knowledge of the path. They are cognized by six consciousnesses. The pervasive and those to be eliminated by the path of cultivation in the three realms increase them.

Only dharmas that are to be eliminated by the path of cultivation are included in fifteen elements and ten sense bases, but not in the aggregates. They are not known by any of the knowledges. They are cognized by five consciousnesses. All the propensities that are to be eliminated by the path of cultivation increase them.

The dharmas not to be eliminated are categorized as the three realms, two sense bases, and five aggregates. They are known by eight knowledges excluding the knowledges of suffering and cause. They are discerned by one consciousness. They are not associated with the increase of any latent tendencies.

Only the dharmas not to be eliminated are not categorized as realms, sense bases, or aggregates. They are known by two knowledges, i.e., the knowledge of cessation and the knowledge of the path. They are not discerned by any consciousness. They are not associated with the increase of any latent tendencies.

The dharmas of the stage of learning are categorized as the three realms, two sense bases, and five aggregates. They are known by seven knowledges excluding the knowledges of suffering, cause, and cessation. They are discerned by one consciousness. They are not associated with the increase of any latent tendencies.

Only the dharmas of the stage of learning are not categorized as realms, sense bases, or aggregates. They are not known by any knowledge. They are not discerned by any consciousness. They are not associated with the increase of any latent tendencies.
The same is so of the dharmas of the stage of no learning.

The dharmas neither of the stage of learning nor of the stage of no learning are categorized as the eighteen elements, twelve sense bases, and five aggregates. They are known by nine knowledges excluding the knowledge of the path. They are discerned by six consciousnesses. They are associated with the increase of all latent tendencies.

Only dharmas that are neither learner nor post-learner, are categorized as fifteen sense bases, ten sense fields, and not included in the aggregates. They are known by three knowledges: knowledge of suffering, knowledge of accumulation, and knowledge of cessation. They are cognized by five consciousnesses, and all proclivities increase them.

Dharmas bound to the desire realm are categorized as eighteen sense bases, twelve sense fields, and five aggregates. They are known by seven knowledges: knowledge of the aggregate of form, knowledge of the aggregate of sensation, knowledge of the aggregate of perception, knowledge of the aggregate of volition, knowledge of the aggregate of consciousness, knowledge of the aggregate of dharmas, and knowledge of the aggregate of the mind. They are cognized by six consciousnesses, and all proclivities of the desire realm increase them.

Only dharmas bound to the desire realm are not categorized as sense bases, not categorized as sense fields, and not categorized as aggregates. They are not known by any knowledges, are cognized by two consciousnesses, and all proclivities of the desire realm increase them.

Dharmas bound to the form realm are categorized as fourteen sense bases, ten sense fields, and five aggregates. They are known by seven knowledges: knowledge of the aggregate of form, knowledge of the aggregate of sensation, knowledge of the aggregate of perception, knowledge of the aggregate of volition, knowledge of the aggregate of consciousness, knowledge of the aggregate of dharmas, and knowledge of the aggregate of the mind. They are cognized by four consciousnesses, and all proclivities of the form realm increase them.

Only dharmas bound to the form realm are not categorized as sense bases, not categorized as sense fields, and not categorized as aggregates. They are not known by any knowledges, are not cognized by any consciousnesses, and all proclivities of the form realm increase them.

dharmas associated with the formless realm are categorized as the three realms, two sense bases, and four aggregates; they are known by six consciousnesses, excluding the cognition of the law, cognition of another's mind, cognition of cessation, and cognition of the path; they are discerned by one consciousness; all proclivities of the formless realm increase them.

Only dharmas associated with the formless realm are not categorized as realms, sense bases, or aggregates; they are not known by any cognition; they are not discerned by any consciousness; all proclivities of the formless realm increase them.

Unassociated dharmas are categorized as the three realms, two sense bases, and five aggregates; they are known by eight cognitions, excluding the cognition of suffering and the cognition of the cause of suffering; they are discerned by one consciousness; proclivities do not increase them.

Only unassociated dharmas are not categorized as realms, sense bases, or aggregates; they are known by two cognitions, the cognition of cessation and the cognition of the path; they are not discerned by any consciousness; proclivities do not increase them.

Past dharmas are categorized as the eighteen realms, twelve sense bases, and five aggregates; they are known by nine cognitions, excluding the cognition of cessation; they are discerned by six consciousnesses; all proclivities increase them.
Only past dharmas are not categorized as realms, sense bases, or aggregates; they are not known by any cognition; they are not discerned by any consciousness; proclivities do not increase them.
Future and present dharmas are also like this.

Dharmas that are neither past, nor future, nor present are not included in any of the aggregates, one realm, one sense base, are known by six consciousnesses, excluding the cognition of the cessation of suffering, the cognition of the path, and the cognition of others' minds, are cognized by one consciousness, and are not associated with any latent afflictions.

Only dharmas that are neither past, nor future, nor present are not included in any of the realms, sense bases, or aggregates, are known by one cognition, namely the cognition of cessation, are not cognized by any consciousness, and are not associated with any latent afflictions.

Dharmas included in the noble truth of suffering are included in eighteen realms, twelve sense bases, and five aggregates, are known by seven cognitions, excluding the cognition of the cause of suffering, the cognition of cessation, and the cognition of the path, are cognized by six consciousnesses, and are associated with all latent afflictions.

Only dharmas included in the noble truth of suffering are not included in any of the realms, sense bases, or aggregates, are known by one cognition, namely the cognition of suffering, are not cognized by any consciousness, and are not associated with any latent afflictions.

Dharmas included in the noble truth of the cause of suffering are included in eighteen realms, twelve sense bases, and five aggregates, are known by seven cognitions, excluding the cognition of suffering, the cognition of cessation, and the cognition of the path, are cognized by six consciousnesses, and are associated with all latent afflictions.

The dharmas included in the truth of the origination of suffering are not included in the realms, not included in the sense bases, and not included in the aggregates. They are known by one kind of knowledge, which is the knowledge of the origination of suffering. They are not objects of the consciousnesses. They are not associated with the latent proclivities.

The dharmas included in the truth of the cessation of suffering are included in one realm, one sense base, and are not included in the aggregates. They are known by six kinds of knowledge, excluding the knowledge of the cessation of suffering, the knowledge of the origination of suffering, and the knowledge of the path. They are objects of one kind of consciousness. They are not associated with the latent proclivities.

The dharmas included in the truth of the cessation of suffering alone are not included in the realms, not included in the sense bases, and not included in the aggregates. They are known by one kind of knowledge, which is the knowledge of the cessation of suffering. They are not objects of the consciousnesses. They are not associated with the latent proclivities.

The dharmas included in the truth of the path are included in three realms, two sense bases, and five aggregates. They are known by seven kinds of knowledge, excluding the knowledge of the cessation of suffering, the knowledge of the origination of suffering, and the knowledge of the path. They are objects of one kind of consciousness. They are not associated with the latent proclivities.

The dharmas included in the truth of the path alone are not included in the realms, not included in the sense bases, and not included in the aggregates. They are known by one kind of knowledge, which is the knowledge of the path. They are not objects of the consciousnesses. They are not associated with the latent proclivities.

The dharmas not subsumed by the truths are not subsumed in one realm, one sense base, and one aggregate. They are known by one kind of knowledge, namely conventional knowledge. They are cognized by one kind of consciousness. No proclivities increase in them.

Only the dharmas not subsumed by the truths are not subsumed in any realms, sense bases, or aggregates. They are not known by any kinds of knowledge. They are not cognized by any kinds of consciousness. No proclivities increase in them.

The dharmas to be eliminated by [the path of] seeing suffering are subsumed in three realms, two sense bases, and four aggregates. They are known by eight kinds of knowledge, excluding the knowledge of cessation and the knowledge of the path. They are cognized by one kind of consciousness. All those to be eliminated by [the path of] seeing suffering and the pervasive proclivities eliminated by [the path of] seeing the origin [of suffering] increase in them.

Only the dharmas to be eliminated by [the path of] seeing suffering are not subsumed in any realms, sense bases, or aggregates. They are not known by any kinds of knowledge. They are not cognized by any kinds of consciousness. The non-pervasive proclivities eliminated by [the path of] seeing suffering increase in them.

The dharmas to be eliminated by [the path of] seeing the origin [of suffering] are subsumed in three realms, two sense bases, and four aggregates. They are known by eight kinds of knowledge, excluding the knowledge of cessation and the knowledge of the path. They are cognized by one kind of consciousness. All those to be eliminated by [the path of] seeing the origin [of suffering] and the pervasive proclivities eliminated by [the path of] seeing suffering increase in them.

The aggregates, elements, and sense bases that are abandoned by insight into the truth of origination are not included in the aggregates, elements, and sense bases, are not known by any of the knowledges, are not cognized by any of the consciousnesses, and the non-pervasive proclivities abandoned by insight into the truth of origination increase in them.

The aggregates, elements, and sense bases that are abandoned by insight into the truth of cessation are included in three realms, two sense bases, and four aggregates, are known by eight knowledges excluding the knowledge of cessation and the knowledge of the path, are cognized by one consciousness, and the proclivities abandoned by insight into the truth of cessation and the pervasive proclivities increase in them.

The aggregates, elements, and sense bases that are abandoned by insight into the truth of cessation alone are not included in the aggregates, elements, and sense bases, are not known by any of the knowledges, are not cognized by any of the consciousnesses, and all the proclivities abandoned by insight into the truth of cessation increase in them.

The aggregates, elements, and sense bases that are abandoned by insight into the truth of the path are included in three realms, two sense bases, and four aggregates, are known by eight knowledges excluding the knowledge of cessation and the knowledge of the path, are cognized by one consciousness, and the proclivities abandoned by insight into the truth of the path and the pervasive proclivities increase in them.

The aggregates, elements, and sense bases that are abandoned by insight into the truth of the path alone are not included in the aggregates, elements, and sense bases, are not known by any of the knowledges, are not cognized by any of the consciousnesses, and all the proclivities abandoned by insight into the truth of the path increase in them.

Dharmas to be eliminated by cultivation are categorized as eighteen sense bases, twelve sense fields, and five aggregates. They are known by eight knowledges excluding the knowledge of cessation and the knowledge of the path. They are discerned by six consciousnesses and are increased by all the proclivities eliminated by the path of cultivation and by the universal proclivities.

Dharmas that are eliminated only by cultivation are categorized as fifteen sense bases and ten sense fields, but are not categorized as aggregates. They are not known by any of the ten knowledges. They are discerned by five consciousnesses and are increased by all the proclivities eliminated by the path of cultivation.

Dharmas that are not eliminated are categorized as three sense bases, two sense fields, and five aggregates. They are known by eight knowledges excluding the knowledge of suffering and the knowledge of the cause of suffering. They are discerned by one consciousness and are not increased by any of the proclivities.

Dharmas that are not eliminated are not categorized as sense bases, sense fields, or aggregates. They are known by two knowledges, the knowledge of cessation and the knowledge of the path. They are not discerned by any of the six consciousnesses and are not increased by any of the proclivities.

The aggregate of form is categorized as eleven sense bases, eleven sense fields, and one aggregate. It is known by eight knowledges excluding the knowledge of othersâ€™ minds and the knowledge of cessation. It is discerned by six consciousnesses and is increased by the universal proclivities of the realm of desire and the realm of form and by the proclivities eliminated by the path of cultivation.

Only the form aggregate is included in ten elements, ten sense bases, and one aggregate. It is not known by knowledge, is cognized by five consciousnesses, and is not associated with or increased by latent afflictions.

The feeling aggregate is included in one element, one sense base, and one aggregate. It is known by nine knowledges excluding the knowledge of cessation, is cognized by one consciousness, and is associated with and increased by all latent afflictions.

Only the feeling aggregate, not included in elements or sense bases, is included in one aggregate. It is not known by knowledge, is not cognized by consciousness, and is not associated with or increased by latent afflictions.
The perception and formation aggregates are also like this.

The consciousness aggregate is included in seven elements, one sense base, and one aggregate. It is known by nine knowledges excluding the knowledge of cessation, is cognized by one consciousness, and is associated with and increased by all latent afflictions.

Only the consciousness aggregate, included in seven elements, one sense base, and one aggregate, is not known by knowledge, is not cognized by consciousness, and is not associated with or increased by latent afflictions.

The eye sense base is included in one element, one sense base, and one aggregate. It is known by seven knowledges excluding the knowledge of others' minds, the knowledge of cessation, and the knowledge of the path. It is cognized by one consciousness. It is associated with and increased by the universal and specific contaminants of the desire and form realms.

Only the eye sense base is included in one element and one sense base, is not included in the aggregates, is not known by any cognition, is cognized by one kind of consciousness, and is not associated with any latent afflictions.
The ear, nose, tongue, and body sense bases are also like this.

The form sense base is included in one element, one sense base, and one aggregate, is known by seven cognitions excluding cognition of others' minds, path cognition, and cessation cognition, is cognized by two kinds of consciousness, and is associated with latent afflictions to be eliminated by the paths of desire and form realms.

Only the form sense base is included in one element and one sense base, is not included in the aggregates, is not known by any cognition, is cognized by one kind of consciousness, and is not associated with any latent afflictions.
The sound and tangible object sense bases are also like this.

The smell sense base is included in one element, one sense base, and one aggregate, is known by six cognitions excluding cognition of the class, cognition of others' minds, path cognition, and cessation cognition, is cognized by two kinds of consciousness, and is associated with latent afflictions to be eliminated by the paths of desire realm and cultivation.

Only the smell sense base is included in one element and one sense base, is not included in the aggregates, is not known by any cognition, is cognized by one kind of consciousness, and is not associated with any latent afflictions.
The taste sense base is also like this.

The sense field of mind is included in seven elements, one sense base, and one aggregate. It is known by nine knowledges except for the knowledge of cessation. It is cognized by one consciousness. All proclivities increase it.
Only the sense field of mind is included in seven elements, one sense base, and one aggregate. It is not known by any knowledge. It is not cognized by any consciousness. No proclivities increase it.
The sense field of mental objects is included in one element, one sense base, and four aggregates. It is known by ten knowledges. It is cognized by one consciousness. All proclivities increase it.

Only the sense field of mental objects is included in one element, one sense base, and three aggregates. It is known by one knowledge, namely the knowledge of cessation. It is not cognized by any consciousness. No proclivities increase it.

The eye element is included in one element, one sense base, and one aggregate. It is known by seven knowledges, excluding the knowledge of others' minds, the knowledge of cessation, and the knowledge of the path. It is cognized by one consciousness. Proclivities of the desire and form realms, and those to be eliminated by cultivation increase it.

Only the eye element is included in one element and one sense base. It is not included in any aggregate. It is not known by any knowledge. It is not cognized by any consciousness. No proclivities increase it.
The same applies to the ear, nose, tongue, and body elements.

The form element is included in one element, one sense base, and one aggregate. It is known by seven knowledges, excluding the knowledge of cessation and the knowledge of the path. It is the object of two consciousnesses. It is the object of the universal and particular defilements of the desire and form realms that are to be eliminated by cultivation.

Only the form element is included in one element and one sense base. It is not included in any aggregates. It is not known by any knowledges. It is the object of one consciousness. It is not the object of any defilements that are to be eliminated by cultivation.
The sound and tangible elements are also like this.

The odor element is included in one element, one sense base, and one aggregate. It is known by six knowledges, excluding the knowledge of the classes of spiritual powers, the knowledge of others' minds, the knowledge of cessation, and the knowledge of the path. It is the object of two consciousnesses. It is the object of the universal and particular defilements of the desire realm that are to be eliminated by cultivation.

Only the odor element is included in one element and one sense base. It is not included in any aggregates. It is not known by any knowledges. It is the object of one consciousness. It is not the object of any defilements that are to be eliminated by cultivation.
The taste element is also like this.
The mind element is like the mind sense base.
The dharma element is like the dharma sense base.

The eye-consciousness element is included in two elements, one sense base, and one aggregate. It is known by eight knowledges, excluding the knowledge of cessation and the knowledge of the path. It is cognized by one consciousness, and the entanglements belonging to the sense-sphere and the form-sphere, as well as those to be abandoned by the path of cultivation, increase in relation to it.

The eye-consciousness element alone is included in one element, not in a sense base, and not in an aggregate. It is not known by any knowledge, it is not cognized by any consciousness, and no entanglements increase in relation to it.
The ear-consciousness element and the body-consciousness element are also like this.

The nose-consciousness element is included in two elements, one sense base, and one aggregate. It is known by seven knowledges, excluding the knowledge of the classes of sentient beings, the knowledge of cessation, and the knowledge of the path. It is cognized by one consciousness, and the entanglements belonging to the sense-sphere, as well as those to be abandoned by the path of cultivation, increase in relation to it.

The nose-consciousness element alone is included in one element, not in a sense base, and not in an aggregate. It is not known by any knowledge, it is not cognized by any consciousness, and no entanglements increase in relation to it.
The tongue-consciousness element is also like this.

The mind-consciousness element is included in two elements, one sense base, and one aggregate. It is known by nine knowledges, excluding the knowledge of cessation. It is cognized by one consciousness, and all entanglements increase in relation to it.

Only the mental consciousness element is included in one element, one sense base, and one aggregate. It is not known by any of the knowledges, is cognized by one consciousness, and is not associated with any of the latent afflictions.

The eye faculty is included in one element, one sense base, and one aggregate. It is known by seven knowledges, excluding the knowledge of cessation and the knowledge of the path. It is cognized by one consciousness, and is associated with the latent afflictions that are universal in the desire and form realms, and those that are eliminated by cultivation.

The eye faculty is included in one element, one sense base, and is not included in any of the aggregates. It is not known by any of the knowledges, is not cognized by any of the consciousnesses, and is not associated with any of the latent afflictions.
The same applies to the ear, nose, tongue, and body faculties.

The female faculty is included in one element, one sense base, and one aggregate. It is known by six knowledges, excluding the knowledge of the classes of spiritual powers, the knowledge of others' minds, the knowledge of cessation, and the knowledge of the path. It is cognized by one consciousness, and is associated with the latent afflictions that are universal in the desire realm, and those that are eliminated by cultivation.

Only the female faculty is not included in any of the elements, sense bases, or aggregates. It is not known by any of the knowledges, is not cognized by any of the consciousnesses, and is not associated with any of the latent afflictions.
The same applies to the male faculty.

The faculty of life-force is included in one element, one sense base, and one aggregate. It is known by seven knowledges, excluding the knowledge of cessation and the knowledge of the path. It is cognized by one consciousness. It is increased by the universal contaminants of the three realms and by the contaminants to be abandoned by cultivation.

Only the faculty of life-force is not included in elements, sense bases, or aggregates. It is not known by any knowledge. It is not cognized by any consciousness. It is not increased by any contaminants.
The faculty of thought is as explained in the sense base of thought.

The faculty of pleasure is included in one element, one sense base, and one aggregate. It is known by nine knowledges, excluding the knowledge of cessation. It is cognized by one consciousness. It is increased by all contaminants of the form realm, by the universal contaminants of the desire realm, and by the contaminants to be abandoned by cultivation.

Only the faculty of pleasure is not included in elements, sense bases, or aggregates. It is not known by any knowledge. It is not cognized by any consciousness. It is not increased by any contaminants.

The faculty of pain is included in one element, one sense base, and one aggregate. It is known by seven knowledges, excluding the knowledge of the classes, the knowledge of cessation, and the knowledge of the path. It is cognized by one consciousness. It is increased by the universal contaminants of the desire realm and by the contaminants to be abandoned by cultivation.

The faculty of suffering is not included in the aggregates, sense bases, or elements, is not known by any of the knowledges, is not cognized by any of the consciousnesses, and is not associated with any of the latent afflictions.

The faculty of joy is included in one aggregate, one sense base, and one element; it is known by nine knowledges excluding the knowledge of cessation; it is cognized by one consciousness; it is associated with all latent afflictions in the form realm, excluding doubt and ignorance associated with it in the desire realm, and all other latent afflictions in the desire realm.

The faculty of joy alone is not included in the aggregates, sense bases, or elements; it is not known by any of the knowledges, is not cognized by any of the consciousnesses, and is not associated with any of the latent afflictions.

The faculty of sorrow is included in one aggregate, one sense base, and one element; it is known by seven knowledges excluding the knowledge of cessation, the knowledge of the path, and the knowledge of varieties; it is cognized by one consciousness; it is associated with all latent afflictions in the desire realm.

The faculty of sorrow alone is not included in the aggregates, sense bases, or elements; it is not known by any of the knowledges, is not cognized by any of the consciousnesses, and is not associated with any of the latent afflictions.

The faculty of equanimity is included in one aggregate, one sense base, and one element; it is known by nine knowledges excluding the knowledge of cessation; it is cognized by one consciousness; it is associated with all latent afflictions.

Only the faculty of equanimity is not included in the realms, not included in the sense bases, and not included in the aggregates, is not known by any of the knowledges, is not cognized by any of the consciousnesses, and is not associated with any of the latent afflictions.

The faculty of faith is included in one realm, one sense base, and one aggregate. It is known by nine knowledges, excluding the knowledge of cessation. It is cognized by one consciousness. It is associated with the afflictions of the three realms that are to be eliminated by cultivation.

Only the faculty of faith is not included in the realms, not included in the sense bases, and not included in the aggregates, is not known by any of the knowledges, is not cognized by any of the consciousnesses, and is not associated with any of the latent afflictions.
The faculties of zeal, mindfulness, concentration, and wisdom are also like this.

The faculty of understanding the unknown is included in three realms, two sense bases, and three aggregates. It is known by seven knowledges, excluding the knowledges of suffering, origination, and cessation. It is cognized by one consciousness. It is not associated with any of the latent afflictions.

Only the faculty of understanding the unknown is not included in the realms, not included in the sense bases, and not included in the aggregates, is not known by any of the knowledges, is not cognized by any of the consciousnesses, and is not associated with any of the latent afflictions.
The faculties of understanding and complete understanding are also like this.

The proclivities eliminated by [the path of] vision of suffering in the desire realm are included in one realm, one sense base, and one aggregate. They are known by seven knowledges, excluding the knowledge of cessation and the knowledge of the path. They are cognized by one consciousness. All those eliminated by [the path of] vision of suffering in the desire realm and the pervasive proclivities eliminated by [the path of] vision of origination in the desire realm increase them.

Only the proclivities eliminated by [the path of] vision of suffering in the desire realm are not included in realms, sense bases, or aggregates. They are not known by any knowledges. They are not cognized by any consciousnesses. No proclivities increase them.

The proclivities eliminated by [the path of] vision of origination in the desire realm are included in one realm, one sense base, and one aggregate. They are known by seven knowledges, excluding the knowledge of cessation and the knowledge of the path. They are cognized by one consciousness. All those eliminated by [the path of] vision of origination in the desire realm and the pervasive proclivities eliminated by [the path of] vision of suffering in the desire realm increase them.

Only the proclivities eliminated by [the path of] vision of origination in the desire realm are not included in realms, sense bases, or aggregates. They are not known by any knowledges. They are not cognized by any consciousnesses. No proclivities increase them.

The proclivities eliminated by [the path of] insight into the cessation [of the truths] in the sense-world sphere are included in one element, one sense, and one aggregate. They are known by seven kinds of knowledge, excluding the knowledge of cessation, the knowledge of the path, and the knowledge of the principle of conditioned origination. They are cognized by one kind of consciousness, excluding the non-universal ignorance eliminated by [the path of] insight into the cessation [of the truths] in the sense-world sphere. All the other proclivities eliminated by [the path of] insight into the cessation [of the truths] in the sense-world sphere and the universal proclivities increase in accordance with them.

Only the proclivities eliminated by [the path of] insight into the cessation [of the truths] in the sense-world sphere are not included in the elements, sense bases, or aggregates. They are not known by any kind of knowledge. They are not cognized by any kind of consciousness. No proclivities increase in accordance with them.

The proclivities eliminated by [the path of] insight into the path [of the truths] in the sense-world sphere are included in one element, one sense, and one aggregate. They are known by seven kinds of knowledge, excluding the knowledge of the path, the knowledge of the principle of conditioned origination, and the knowledge of cessation. They are cognized by one kind of consciousness, excluding the non-universal ignorance eliminated by [the path of] insight into the path [of the truths] in the sense-world sphere. All the other proclivities eliminated by [the path of] insight into the path [of the truths] in the sense-world sphere and the universal proclivities increase in accordance with them.

Only the proclivities eliminated by [the path of] insight into the path [of the truths] in the sense-world sphere are not included in the elements, sense bases, or aggregates. They are not known by any kind of knowledge. They are not cognized by any kind of consciousness. No proclivities increase in accordance with them.

The proclivities eliminated by cultivation in the realm of desire are included in one realm, one sense base, and one aggregate. They are known by seven knowledges, excluding the knowledge of the class, cessation, and path. They are cognized by one consciousness, i.e., the mental consciousness. All proclivities eliminated by cultivation in the realm of desire and the universal proclivities increase it.

Only the proclivities eliminated by cultivation in the realm of desire are not included in any realm, sense base, or aggregate. They are not known by any knowledge. They are not cognized by any consciousness. No proclivities increase them.

The proclivities eliminated by seeing suffering in the realm of form are included in one realm, one sense base, and one aggregate. They are known by seven knowledges, excluding the knowledge of the dharma, cessation, and path. They are cognized by one consciousness, i.e., the mental consciousness. All proclivities eliminated by seeing suffering in the realm of form and the universal proclivities eliminated by seeing the arising of the realm of form increase it.

Only the proclivities eliminated by seeing suffering in the realm of form are not included in any realm, sense base, or aggregate. They are not known by any knowledge. They are not cognized by any consciousness. No proclivities increase them.

The proclivities eliminated by insight into the truth of the origin in the realm of form are included in one realm, one sense base, and one aggregate. They are known by seven kinds of knowledge, excluding the knowledge of cessation and the knowledge of the path. They are discerned by one kind of consciousness. The proclivities eliminated by insight into the truth of the origin in the realm of form and the universally-pervasive proclivities eliminated by insight into the truth of suffering increase.

Only the proclivities eliminated by insight into the truth of the origin in the realm of form are not included in any realms, sense bases, or aggregates. They are not known by any kinds of knowledge. They are not discerned by any kinds of consciousness. They are not increased by any proclivities.

The proclivities eliminated by insight into the truth of cessation in the realm of form are included in one realm, one sense base, and one aggregate. They are known by seven kinds of knowledge, excluding the knowledge of cessation and the knowledge of the path. They are discerned by one kind of consciousness. With the exception of the non-pervasive ignorance eliminated by insight into the truth of cessation in the realm of form, all the other proclivities eliminated by insight into the truth of cessation in the realm of form and the universally-pervasive proclivities increase.

Only the proclivities eliminated by insight into the truth of cessation in the realm of form are not included in any realms, sense bases, or aggregates. They are not known by any kinds of knowledge. They are not discerned by any kinds of consciousness. They are not increased by any proclivities.

The proclivities eliminated by the path of insight in the realm of form are included in one realm, one sense base, and one aggregate. They are known by seven knowledges, excluding the knowledge of cessation and the knowledge of the path. They are discerned by one consciousness, excluding the non-universal ignorance eliminated by the path of insight in the realm of form. The remaining proclivities eliminated by the path of insight in the formless realm and the universal proclivities increase in them.

Only the proclivities eliminated by the path of insight in the realm of form are not included in a realm, a sense base, or an aggregate. They are not known by any knowledge. They are not discerned by any consciousness. No proclivities increase in them.

The proclivities eliminated by cultivation in the realm of form are included in one realm, one sense base, and one aggregate. They are known by seven knowledges, excluding the knowledge of cessation and the knowledge of the path. They are discerned by one consciousness. The proclivities eliminated by cultivation in the realm of form and the universal proclivities increase in them.

Only the proclivities eliminated by cultivation in the realm of form are not included in a realm, a sense base, or an aggregate. They are not known by any knowledge. They are not discerned by any consciousness. No proclivities increase in them.

The proclivities eliminated by [the path of] insight into suffering in the formless realm are categorized as one realm, one sense base, and one aggregate. They are known by six kinds of knowledge, excluding the knowledge of the factors, the knowledge of anotherâ€™s mind, the knowledge of the destruction , and the knowledge of the path. They are discerned by one kind of consciousness. The proclivities eliminated by insight into suffering in the formless realm and the universally eliminated proclivities eliminated by insight into the origin are the only ones that increase them.

Only the proclivities eliminated by insight into suffering in the formless realm are not categorized as a realm, a sense base, or an aggregate. They are not known by any kind of knowledge, are not discerned by any kind of consciousness, and are not increased by any kind of proclivity.

The proclivities eliminated by [the path of] insight into the origin in the formless realm are categorized as one realm, one sense base, and one aggregate. They are known by six kinds of knowledge, excluding the knowledge of the factors, the knowledge of anotherâ€™s mind, the knowledge of the destruction , and the knowledge of the path. They are discerned by one kind of consciousness. The proclivities eliminated by insight into the origin in the formless realm and the universally eliminated proclivities eliminated by insight into suffering are the only ones that increase them.

Only the proclivities eliminated by insight into the origin in the formless realm are not categorized as a realm, a sense base, or an aggregate. They are not known by any kind of knowledge, are not discerned by any kind of consciousness, and are not increased by any kind of proclivity.

The proclivities eliminated by the path of insight into the truths of cessation in the formless realm are categorized as one realm, one sense base, and one aggregate. They are known by six kinds of knowledge, excluding knowledge of the mind of another, the knowledge of extinction, and the knowledge of the path. They are discerned by one consciousness, excluding the non-pervading ignorance eliminated by the path of insight into the truths of cessation in the formless realm. The remaining proclivities eliminated by the path of insight into the truths of cessation in the formless realm and the universal proclivities increase in accordance with it.

Only the proclivities eliminated by the path of insight into the truths of cessation in the formless realm are not categorized as a realm, a sense base, or an aggregate. They are not known by any kind of knowledge, are not discerned by any kind of consciousness, and no proclivities increase in accordance with them.

The proclivities eliminated by the path of insight into the truths of the path in the formless realm are categorized as one realm, one sense base, and one aggregate. They are known by six kinds of knowledge, excluding knowledge of the mind of another, the knowledge of extinction, and the knowledge of the path. They are discerned by one consciousness, excluding the non-pervading ignorance eliminated by the path of insight into the truths of the path in the formless realm. The remaining proclivities eliminated by the path of insight into the truths of the path in the formless realm and the universal proclivities increase in accordance with it.

Only the proclivities eliminated by the path of insight into the truths of the path in the formless realm are not categorized as a realm, a sense base, or an aggregate. They are not known by any kind of knowledge, are not discerned by any kind of consciousness, and no proclivities increase in accordance with them.

The latent afflictions eliminated by cultivation in the formless realm are included in one realm, one sense base, and one aggregate. They are known by six knowledges: knowledge of the law, knowledge of the path, and knowledge of cessation are excluded. They are discerned by one consciousness. All the latent afflictions eliminated by cultivation in the formless realm and the universal ones increase.

Only the latent afflictions eliminated by cultivation in the formless realm are not included in realms, sense bases, or aggregates. They are not known by any knowledge. They are not discerned by any consciousness. They are not increased by any latent afflictions.ğŸ”½Here is the corrected and aligned text:
